title: Information Exposure Through Directory Listing vulnerability on 8 vcache**.usw2.snappytv.com websites

profile.name: Twitter
profile.about: Twitter helps you create and share ideas and information instantly, without barriers.

vulnerability_information:
**Summary:** Researcher has found directory listing exposure to several vcache**.usw2.snappytv.com websites. A directory listing provides an attacker with the complete index of all the resources located inside of the directory as well as download or access its contents. 

While the researcher did not dig deeper on to the available files, it might be possible that these websites host sensitive information like private videos which can publicly be downloaded or accessed by any user.

## Steps To Reproduce:

Browse to the URLs below to see the vulnerability.

1. http://vcache01.usw2.snappytv.com/media/
2. http://vcache02.usw2.snappytv.com/media/
3. http://vcache03.usw2.snappytv.com/media/
4. http://vcache04.usw2.snappytv.com/media/
5. http://vcache05.usw2.snappytv.com/media/
6. http://vcache06.usw2.snappytv.com/media/
7. http://vcache07.usw2.snappytv.com/media/
8. http://vcache08.usw2.snappytv.com/media/

## Impact:
A directory listing provides an attacker with the complete index of all the resources located inside of the directory. The specific risks and consequences vary depending on which files are listed and accessible. The files can possibly expose sensitive information as well as sensitive files like private videos or photos.

## Supporting Material/References:
**Proof**
{F373267}

## Impact

A directory listing provides an attacker with the complete index of all the resources located inside of the directory. The specific risks and consequences vary depending on which files are listed and accessible. The files can possibly expose sensitive information as well as sensitive files like private videos or photos.

While the researcher did not dig deeper on to the available files, it might be possible that these websites host sensitive information like private videos which can publicly be downloaded or accessed by any user.

activities.message:
Thank you for your report.

Please keep in mind that our HackerOne program generally does not accept theoretical or potential vulnerabilities. 
 These directories seem to contain only publicly accessible media files, though it looks like many of the files themselves aren't actually accessible.  Can you be more specific as to what in these directories you feel is sensitive?  Simply being able to look at the directory structure of these URLs isn't a vulnerability in-and-of itself.

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security!
activities.markdown_message:
Thank you for your report.

Please keep in mind that our HackerOne program generally does not accept theoretical or potential vulnerabilities.
These directories seem to contain only publicly accessible media files, though it looks like many of the files themselves aren't actually accessible. Can you be more specific as to what in these directories you feel is sensitive? Simply being able to look at the directory structure of these URLs isn't a vulnerability in-and-of itself.

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security!

activities.message:
Hi @bugtriage-josh,

These directory listing exposure are cached websites of the ``media.snappytv.com`` which is used by ``snappytv.com``, since ``snappytv.com`` only accepts corporate account I can't seem to know what items are supposed to be not shared or only be shared to their region and restricted to others. 

Below is the directory listing exposure vulnerability on ``media.snappy.tv``:
http://media.snappytv.com/media/

The items that are being shown are **time dependent** - meaning **depending on the time that the user access the directory listing exposure then a user gain access to the files that are on it**.

If you check on the **time modified** of the directory, you can see that the contents changes. For example below is a screenshot on http://media.snappytv.com/media/ wherein you can see that the time is **recent** as the time screenshot was taken or time the directory has been accessed. 

{F373684}

For example, I have managed to download a full episode of a certain program with file name ``ld360p_507_1541815224.471--959.311c1541816487.332--816.305c1541817612.939--621.615c1541818525.129--850.167c1541819705.416--892.38.mp4`` (video is 476.2 MB and runs for 1 hour and 9 minutes and on a different language that I can't understand) originally available on http://media.snappytv.com/media/video/7/ which existed during the time I tried to access the directory listing. 

{F373707}

Below is a screenshot of the some available files **during the time I accessed the directory listing** which the directory seems to be **time dependent**.

{F373702}

For additional POC, you can use the command: ``wget -r http://media.snappytv.com/media/ -R index.html`` as it will download **currently** available files from the http://media.snappytv.com/media/ which from then you can see that you will have access to certain video files that are available **during the time the command was run**.

Again not sure what items are supposed to be restricted to be shared by the corporations that have been using **snappytv.com** or if possible that it breaks the SnappyTV Twitter's Commitment to GDPR Compliance as described on https://snappytv.zendesk.com/hc/en-us/articles/360000653923-SnappyTV-Twitter-s-Commitment-to-GDPR-Compliance as it seems it is only for corporate accounts.

But nevertheless, one can dump all available files that are accessible because of the directory listing exposure.

Please use command: ``wget -r http://media.snappytv.com/media/ -R index.html`` to download available files during the time you have run the command.

Hi @bugtriage-josh,

These directory listing exposure are cached websites of the media.snappytv.com which is used by snappytv.com, since snappytv.com only accepts corporate account I can't seem to know what items are supposed to be not shared or only be shared to their region and restricted to others.

Below is the directory listing exposure vulnerability on media.snappy.tv:
http://media.snappytv.com/media/

The items that are being shown are time dependent - meaning depending on the time that the user access the directory listing exposure then a user gain access to the files that are on it.

If you check on the time modified of the directory, you can see that the contents changes. For example below is a screenshot on http://media.snappytv.com/media/ wherein you can see that the time is recent as the time screenshot was taken or time the directory has been accessed.

For example, I have managed to download a full episode of a certain program with file name ld360p_507_1541815224.471--959.311c1541816487.332--816.305c1541817612.939--621.615c1541818525.129--850.167c1541819705.416--892.38.mp4 (video is 476.2 MB and runs for 1 hour and 9 minutes and on a different language that I can't understand) originally available on http://media.snappytv.com/media/video/7/ which existed during the time I tried to access the directory listing.

Below is a screenshot of the some available files during the time I accessed the directory listing which the directory seems to be time dependent.

For additional POC, you can use the command: wget -r http://media.snappytv.com/media/ -R index.html as it will download currently available files from the http://media.snappytv.com/media/ which from then you can see that you will have access to certain video files that are available during the time the command was run.

Again not sure what items are supposed to be restricted to be shared by the corporations that have been using snappytv.com or if possible that it breaks the SnappyTV Twitter's Commitment to GDPR Compliance as described on https://snappytv.zendesk.com/hc/en-us/articles/360000653923-SnappyTV-Twitter-s-Commitment-to-GDPR-Compliance as it seems it is only for corporate accounts.

But nevertheless, one can dump all available files that are accessible because of the directory listing exposure.

Please use command: wget -r http://media.snappytv.com/media/ -R index.html to download available files during the time you have run the command.

activities.message:
Hello @ameerpornillos 

We're looking into this, and we'll keep you updated when we have additional information.

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

activities.message:
Thank you for your report. We believe it may be a valid security issue and will investigate it further. It could take some time to find and update the root cause for an issue, so we thank you for your patience.

Thank you for helping keep Twitter secure!
activities.markdown_message:
Thank you for your report. We believe it may be a valid security issue and will investigate it further. It could take some time to find and update the root cause for an issue, so we thank you for your patience.

activities.message: Thank you @bugtriage-alex and @petrilli for the update.
activities.markdown_message: Thank you @bugtriage-alex and @petrilli for the update.

activities.message: Thank you for bringing this issue to our attention. Unfortunately, this report does not fall in scope for a monetary reward at this time. As a reminder, please remember to keep the details of this report private until we have fully investigated and addressed the issue.
activities.markdown_message: Thank you for bringing this issue to our attention. Unfortunately, this report does not fall in scope for a monetary reward at this time. As a reminder, please remember to keep the details of this report private until we have fully investigated and addressed the issue.

activities.message:
We consider this issue to be fixed now. Can you please confirm?

Unfortunately, we do not currently have the ability to provide swag. We appreciate your bringing this to our attention.

Thank you for helping keep Twitter secure!
